content.text:
<task>
tsconfig.json:1-34
```
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "es2017",
    "module": "es2022",
    "lib": ["esnext", "esnext.asynciterable"],
    "moduleResolution": "node",
    "outDir": "./dist",
    "strict": true,
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "skipLibCheck": true,
    "forceConsistentCasingInFileNames": true,
    "baseUrl": ".",
    "paths": {
      "'*"' (see below for file content): ["./src/*"]
    },
    "allowJs": true,
    "noEmit": true,
    "incremental": true,
    "resolveJsonModule": true,
    "isolatedModules": true,
    "jsx": "preserve",
    "plugins": [
      {
        "name": "next"
      }
    ],
    "experimentalDecorators": true,
    "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
    "strictPropertyInitialization": false
  },
  "include": ["src/**/*", ".next/types/**/*.ts"],
  "exclude": ["node_modules"]
}

```

Given the fact that this is a next.js application, is this tsconfig.json correct?  typescript does validate the current code, but I'm not sure if that's because the config matches the reality of the bundler, or just coincidence
</task>
